Steeeeve

Now I voted for Bush and I thought he did a pretty good job from 2000-2004, but it seems now that he just wants to get out. He has done nothing since getting elected. His social security thing failed, he doesn't seem to care too much about Iraq, and he appoints his friend to the Supreme Court. I think Bush hates us all now so he is just giving us the finger and taking it easy for the remaining 3 years. Obviously some of you didn't like anything he did but I'd rather not argue that and I would rather hear from the people that voted for him in '04. The Miers appointment was pretty much the last straw for me...what about any of you?
 
 (note: I really don't want to have dumb comments from democrats like "since he was elected"...please, make a sane thought for once)

 As a life long Republican, I voted for him in 2000, but by 2004 administration policies, actions and deceit had thoroughly turned my stomach. He made me ashamed of the Republican Party. If he persists in expanding our war involvement, I'll again become politically active and do everything in my limited power to help defeat any Republican he endorses and those Republicans who support him. As to his lame duck actions, he needs the next three years and all the presidential pardons he can amass for paybacks. History has little mercy and will view his presidency along the lines of his string of business failures.
OccamsRazor

I remember the day it was announced that Gore had decided to conceide and Bush had won.
 
 I had a sinking feeling in the pit of my stomach when I heard that news.... subsequent events proved my hunch right in way I would enjoy if not for the nature of his mistakes.
 
 Aside from my opposition to his political philosophy, the lack of judgement over Iraq and subsequent destruction of international solidarity post September 11th will surely be remembered as one of the the worst foreign policy desicions in modern times.

 I never had faith in Bush. I really felt my lack of faith was vindicated during the whole "justification du jour" for the Iraq war. Setting the terror alert system to high whenever Kerry got some press and setting it lower when Bush was in the news also helped cement my opinions of him. I guess it was somewhere around there that I stopped being shocked and dismayed over Bush's actions and simply assumed that he would always put the interests of his cronies over the interests of America. Now I can only be pleasantly suprised when Bush speaks. :)
georged

I use particular points in my response to illustrate my personal reactions in 'losing faith' in current administration prior to 2004 and separate that reasoning from useless emotional opinions:
 
 1. Writing 'tax refund' checks to low-middle income families with dependent children to gain popularity 
 2. Medicare prescription plan 
 3. Attempted privatization of SS to drive stagnant equity markets, 
 4. Tariff based foreign policy to protect inefficient US industry 
 5. The largest expansion of federal government in history
 6. Tax cuts that reduced federal revenue base in a time of industrial decline with no hope of recapture due to non-competitive industry 
 6. Reduction of state revenue sharing to create an illusion of lower national deficit spending, pushing debt down throughout the system 
 7. The blatant deception used to invade Iraq and immerse us in a quagmire
 8. Driving GDP through public and consumer debt 
 
 All prior to 2004 and 180-degrees from traditional conservative Republican values.
daewoo

I'm with George. I voted for Bush originally, but the acts of his first term completely soured me and frankly made me ashamed of the republican party. I actually found myself hoping Kerry would win round 2.
jsaid2009

Well, you guys convinced me. I will not be voting for Bush in 2008.
 emoticon_xhoho
Steeeeve

I'm with George. I voted for Bush originally, but the acts of his first term completely soured me and frankly made me ashamed of the republican party. I actually found myself hoping Kerry would win round 2.

 
 I was actually torn between Bugs Bunny and Bush in 04. I ended up voting for Bush just because Kerry needed someone to tell him to sit down and shut up. I still don't think Bush "LIED" about the reasons to go to Iraq, although many think he did. I think lying is different from being flat wrong. Either way, that was not a good move but wasn't really enough to push me over the edge...i'm a forgiving person, and he did do a good job with 9/11 response. Then during the 2004 election we started to notice that no one running was worth a darn. Once Bush was elected he decided that everything he ran on was going to the back burner so he pulled out Social Security (which is fine) but he only mentioned it once during the Convention. He then said he would appoint people like Scalia and Thomas (who are smart guys even if you don't like them) and he almost did with Roberts but failed with Miers...and that was it. The idea of the Republican party in VA has seemed to spread to the country....get the best ideas and have the worst man screw them all up. I'm not saying the Democrats have done any better. They just whine all the time like I am doing now. Ugh, Bugs Bunny would have been a fine choice.
PoohBear

whats hasnt bush done exactly? what is it you would like him todo? why dont you run for president if you think you can do a better job.. with all the pressure he has on him! would you be able to run the COUNTRY knowing that someone might be mad at you and wanna shoot you everyday... maybe even think a plane might fly into the building.. think about it! i think hes doin a pretty darn good job of it!
daewoo

I was actually torn between Bugs Bunny and Bush in 04. I ended up voting for Bush just because Kerry needed someone to tell him to sit down and shut up. I still don't think Bush "LIED" about the reasons to go to Iraq, although many think he did. I think lying is different from being flat wrong. Either way, that was not a good move but wasn't really enough to push me over the edge...i'm a forgiving person, and he did do a good job with 9/11 response. 

 
 I was torn on that one, until the downing street memo, and the final reports from the UN weapon inspectors, and then the whole mess with Chalabi and his statements that the Bush administration "prodded" him to lie to intelligence sourses from other nations about Iraqs WMDs.
 
 When you get to the point that memos are being leaked about Bush "fixing" the intel, it is time to quit calling it the biggest blunder of the century and admit to ourselves that we were lied to. The alternative may be worse. We know he had a copy of the UN weapons ispectors reports when he made the decision, we know he fixed the intel. If he did not lie, what he DID do was completely and totally ignore all the intel that we had that was even marginally reliable, instead relying on intel that had been shown as unreliable, and launched us on a trillion dollar crusade. The poor judgement that shows is possibly more dangerous than having a liar in the whitehouse. What it coems down to is that the guy is either a liar, or an idiot. I would rather he be a liar. President of the United states is too important a position ot have an idiot there.
 
 
 Then during the 2004 election we started to notice that no one running was worth a darn. Once Bush was elected he decided that everything he ran on was going to the back burner so he pulled out Social Security (which is fine) but he only mentioned it once during the Convention. 
 
 
 I think he realized that he was not going to get the stuff he ran on. Things like tort reform look great, until people relaiuze that you really cannot do it without putting the American public wholly at the mercy of big business. His prescription drug plan sounded great, until the price tag came along, and it looked even worse once it ws discovered that those who drafted it essentially conspired with drug manufacturers, who raised prices when the new plan went into effect. In many cases, the end user is paying the exact sdame amount for their prescription, PLUS the taxpayer is kickign in quite a bit. It turned out to be nothing but a big give away to pharmaceutical companies.
 
 The problem is that he ran on a platform of special interests and corporate greed. The Americna public, not beign the sharpest tools in the shed, take a while to figure such things out. These things that sounded good as comapingn sound bytes are almost impossible to sell when they are actually out in the open, with all the down sides revealed.
 
 
 He then said he would appoint people like Scalia and Thomas (who are smart guys even if you don't like them) and he almost did with Roberts but failed with Miers...and that was it. 
 
 
 Failed with Miers? He chose a corporate lawyer with almost no background in constitituional law. Failed is an understatement.

whats hasnt bush done exactly? what is it you would like him todo? why dont you run for president if you think you can do a better job.. with all the pressure he has on him! would you be able to run the COUNTRY knowing that someone might be mad at you and wanna shoot you everyday... maybe even think a plane might fly into the building.. think about it! i think hes doin a pretty darn good job of it!

 
 Well that's kind of in the job description. There's a reason many of us didn't run, because we didn't think we could handle it. He ran for president. He knew coming in that he would have to be the commander in cheif of our military and be able to act fast. He had plenty of time to think about court nominees. I would be scared to death knowing that my decisions might have an impact on whether people in my country would die or not. But he raised the money, got the support, and ran. He told us he thought he could do it. While you may argue he did do a good job, the fact that he has a tough job is no excuse.

 I will answer, despite the fact that you quoted that wench.
 
 I actually thought that Bush appointing a justice who did not have much (or any) experience as a judge was a good thing. Most of the judges I know are kind of off in their own little world. I thought that putting somebody on the bench who does not have a long history as a judge might be refreshing. There is certainly plenty of precendence for it.
 
 That said, it would be nice if he had sppointed somebody with SOME qualifications. Even if it was just sombody with a long history of constitutional law interest OUTSIDE the legal system, I would have been fine with that. Instead, he appoints a corporate lawyer? WTF? 
 
 Granted a supreme court justice is probably easier than being a regular lawyer because despite the fact that the court is the most powerful in the land, their scope of power is narrowly defined, and they are not required to adhere to judicial precedence, even precedent set by earlier supreme courts.
 
 That said, if Bush was looking for somebody to further his personal agenda for years to come, she was a good choice. She has a long history of using the law to help giant corporations, and enormously wealthy individuals, use the system to screw over the american public. Since that has largely been Bushs primary funciton during his presidency, they are just peas in a pod.
